law.catch_line: Unknown claims against dissolved limited cooperative association.

text.section: A dissolved limited cooperative association may publish notice of its dissolution and request persons having claims against the association to present them in accordance with the notice.

A notice under subsection (1) of this section shall:
Be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the dissolved limited cooperative associationâ€™s principal office is located or, if the association does not have a principal office in the Commonwealth, in the county in which the associationâ€™s registered office is or was last located;
Provide the name of the association and describe the information required to be contained in a claim and provide an address to which the claim is to be sent; and
State that a claim against the association is barred unless an action to enforce the claim is commenced not later than two (2) years after publication of the notice.

If a dissolved limited cooperative association publishes a notice in accordance with subsection (2) of this section, the claim of each of the following claimants is barred unless the claimant commences an action to enforce the claim not later than three (3) years after the first publication date of the notice:
A claimant that is entitled to but did not receive notice in a record under KRS 272A.12-080; or
A claimant whose claim is contingent or based on an event occurring after the effective date of dissolution.

A claim not barred under this section may be enforced:
Against a dissolved limited cooperative association, to the extent of its undistributed assets; or
If the associationâ€™s assets have been distributed in connection with winding up, against a member or holder of financial rights to the extent of that personâ€™s proportionate share of the claim or the associationâ€™s assets distributed to the person in connection with the winding up, whichever is less. The personâ€™s total liability for all claims under this paragraph shall not exceed the total amount of assets distributed to the person as part of the winding up of the association.
